summary: The Project Manager presented the project to the other participants by discussing the aim of creating a new, fashionable remote control device and defined the roles and tasks of each participant. The group introduced themselves to each other and trained themselves how to use the whiteboard tools. The Project Manager discussed the financial goals of the project, including the projected profit aim and price point for the device. The Project Manager gave each participant their assignments. The group then began a discussion of their initial ideas about the remote control and possible features. The Project Manager announced that he would make a report containing the discussion of the group's initial ideas about the device.
actions: The Industrial Designer will prepare a definition of the basic functions that the remote control device will have. The Marketing Expert will define the needs and desires of the user. The User Interface Designer will receive further assignments at a later time. The Project Manager will prepare a report of the initial ideas discussed during the meeting.
decisions: The group decided to consider the following features for the remote control device: universal compatibility with different types of video formatting, combination with other types of devices, and interchangeable faceplates.

ppt.content:
Remote Control Project 
Agenda
Opening
Acquaintance
Tool training 
Project plan
Discussion
Closing (we have 25 minutes!)
IRL
Introductions
Proposal for Protocol – Don’t ask, Don’t tell
Introductions, Background, etc. (have fun if you like)
Our Goal
Remote Control – Reinventing the Wheel
Original
Trendy
User friendly
Project Method
Functional design 
Individual work
Meeting
Conceptual design
Individual work
Meeting
Detailed design
Individual work
Meeting
Tool Training
The absolute Basics – Whiteboard
Write down the name of one of your ‘desert island discs’ and why you’d take it
Or: TV show/Movie you like & Why
Or: Something you love about Edinburgh
Or: Your hometown and something you miss about it
Or: ‘Something you’d like to share with the class’
Project Finance
Selling price: 25 euro
Profit aim: 50 M euro
Market range: international
Production costs: max. 12.50 euro
Discussion
Examples:
Experience with remote controls
First ideas new remote
Novelty?
Price and Finances
Size, Function, etc
Marketing, etc
Closing
Next meeting starts in 30 minutes
Individual actions
ID: the working design
UID: the technical functions design 
ME: the user requirements specification 
Specific instructions will be sent to you by your personal coach.

Interface Concept
Presented by: Ron
User Interface Designer
Method
User interface
The aspects of a computer system or program which can be seen (or heard or otherwise perceived) by the human user
The commands and mechanisms the user uses to control its operation and input data. 
Remote Control Examples
User Interface Components I
Voice recognition:
Stores Up to 80 speech samples
Record own verbal labels connected to remote control functions
A spinning wheel with LC display:
User Interface Components II
A scroll button with integrated push button (such as in modern computer mouse) at the side of the remote: 
User Interface Components III
TV remote control for special user
Program in only the channels you want your kids to watch - all others are automatically blocked!
Program in up to 10, 4-Digit channels. Dedicated buttons make getting to channels easy.
Secured and hidden programming and battery covers protect your settings.
User Interface Components IV
Big Button, Oversized TV Remote is the largest universal remote control available!
This jumbo universal remote control is almost impossible to misplace or lose.  
Personal Preferences
Slightly larger than reg. IPod
Hard plastic casing (stylishly curved)
Changeable casings
Touch screen interface
“Go To” Buttons remain on screen at all times.  I.E. Power, Volume, “Jump”
Voice command system for advanced features
Development of new voice command system with response
Use of recognizable colours and shapes to aid recognition of feature (conform industry standards)
Programmable jokes and lines for remote to say! (FUN)

Technical Functions Design
Presented by: Ron
User Interface Designer
Method
Requirements:
Operate electronic devices
Universal
Possibly operate several different types of devices
Findings
Function of a remote control
	- send messages to the television set.
	Eg.:	"switch on“
			"switch to next channel“
			"switch to channel 9“
			"turn volume up"
Findings II
Complicated Remote
	- many functions
	- user will generally have
	  little use as it is complicated
	- BORING
Findings III
Simple Remote
Few functions
Easy for user to manipulate
Cheap look
BORING!
Personal Preferences
Revolutionize!!       
Attain the functionality of the complicated device
Attain simplicity through a new format of display (user interface)

Components Design
Presented by:  Mr. Participant 2, Industrial Designer
Components
Energy source – lithium or solar cells??
Case – plastic, rubber or wood?; flat, curved or double curved?
Buttons – multiple scroll buttons are possible (cost more b/c require multiple chips). note that, if you use a rubber double curved case, you must use rubber push buttons. Touch screen = many chips = ££££.
Infrared or “visible light”?
Integrated Circuit – aka “chip”, TA11835 
Findings
We are very limited by what our current manufacturers can offer
Should we look to other manufacturers or just make do w/ what we have available?
Personal Preferences
Solar batteries
Visible light signalling
Variety of case materials to suit different tastes (but not different face-plates)

Evaluation criteria
Presented by: Sara,  Marketing Expert
Method
Function
does it work the tv?
Design
is the interface intuitive?
Technology
do the features work?
Aesthetic
does it fulfill our visual style requirements?
Findings
Function 
Turns on, changes channels and volume sufficiently
Design
Interface takes adjusting, but works well
Technology
Features selection solid
Voice recognition work within acceptable range
Aesthetic
Is unique and organic
Evaluation
Seven Point Evaluation Scale of Product Objectives

Detailed Design meeting
Agenda
Opening
PM = secretary (minutes)
Prototype presentation
Finance
Production evaluation
Closing (we have 40 minutes!)
Minutes
Prototype Presentation
Finance
Excel sheet
Calculate production costs
Are the cost under 12.50 euro?
No: 	redesign
Yes: project evaluation (next slide)
Project evaluation
Project process
Satisfaction with, for example:
Room for creativity
Leadership
Teamwork
Means (e.g., whiteboard, digital pens, etc.)
New ideas found?
Closing
Are the costs within the budget?
Is the project evaluated?
Don’t forget to complete final questionnaire and meeting summary!
Then: Celebration!

Functional Requirements
Presented by: Sara, Market Expert
Method
Research Marketing Reports
Usability Testing
Primary uses
Behaviour interface
Usability Questionnaire
Rank features and functions
List likes and dislikes
Survey future features options
Findings 
Basic functions ranked most important
Current remote controls do not match well the operating behavior of the user 
50% frustrated by losing remote 
50% of users say they only use 10% of the buttons 
Personal Preferences
75% find remotes ugly
80% of users would spend more money when a remote control would look fancy
Over 75% of under 35s would like voice recognition
Primary functions should be most important

Interface Concept
Presented by: Ron
User Interface Designer
Method
User interface
The aspects of a computer system or program which can be seen (or heard or otherwise perceived) by the human user
The commands and mechanisms the user uses to control its operation and input data. 
Remote Control Examples
User Interface Components I
Voice recognition:
Stores Up to 80 speech samples
Record own verbal labels connected to remote control functions
A spinning wheel with LC display:
User Interface Components II
A scroll button with integrated push button (such as in modern computer mouse) at the side of the remote: 
User Interface Components III
TV remote control for special user
Program in only the channels you want your kids to watch - all others are automatically blocked!
Program in up to 10, 4-Digit channels. Dedicated buttons make getting to channels easy.
Secured and hidden programming and battery covers protect your settings.
User Interface Components IV
Big Button, Oversized TV Remote is the largest universal remote control available!
This jumbo universal remote control is almost impossible to misplace or lose.  
Personal Preferences
Slightly larger than reg. IPod
Hard plastic casing (stylishly curved)
Changeable casings
Touch screen interface
“Go To” Buttons remain on screen at all times.  I.E. Power, Volume, “Jump”
Voice command system for advanced features
Development of new voice command system with response
Use of recognizable colours and shapes to aid recognition of feature (conform industry standards)
Programmable jokes and lines for remote to say! (FUN)

Remote Control Project 
Agenda
Opening
Acquaintance
Tool training 
Project plan
Discussion
Closing (we have 25 minutes!)
IRL
Introductions
Proposal for Protocol – Don’t ask, Don’t tell
Introductions, Background, etc. (have fun if you like)
Our Goal
Remote Control – Reinventing the Wheel
Original
Trendy
User friendly
Project Method
Functional design 
Individual work
Meeting
Conceptual design
Individual work
Meeting
Detailed design
Individual work
Meeting
Tool Training
The absolute Basics – Whiteboard
Write down the name of one of your ‘desert island discs’ and why you’d take it
Or: TV show/Movie you like & Why
Or: Something you love about Edinburgh
Or: Your hometown and something you miss about it
Or: ‘Something you’d like to share with the class’
Project Finance
Selling price: 25 euro
Profit aim: 50 M euro
Market range: international
Production costs: max. 12.50 euro
Discussion
Examples:
Experience with remote controls
First ideas new remote
Novelty?
Price and Finances
Size, Function, etc
Marketing, etc
Closing
Next meeting starts in 30 minutes
Individual actions
ID: the working design
UID: the technical functions design 
ME: the user requirements specification 
Specific instructions will be sent to you by your personal coach.

Functional Design meeting
Agenda
Opening
Project Manager = secretary (minutes)
Broad Guidelines from the Board
Findings 
Project Questions
Guidelines (restrictions)
Television Only…
Incorporate the Company Colours (black and yellow) and Slogan must be present…
No Teletext (?)
Presentation by ID
Presentation by UID
Presentation by ME
Functional Design 
Need and Desires for the RC?
Who are we selling this to?
How does an RC work?
How can we make it better/smaller/faster/etc?
How can we make it sleek?
Bearing in Mind…
Since it’s only Telly-Relevant
How Slick and High Quality can we make it?
Extra Features?
Ideas from last time
Paging Function
Touch-Screen
Faceplates
Discussion
Closing
After meeting: complete questionnaire and summarization (to be sent by email), then lunch break
Then 30 minutes of individual work
Individual actions
ID: the components concept 
UID: the user interface concept 
ME: trend watching 
Specific instructions will be sent to you by your personal coach.

Technical Functions Design
Presented by: Ron
User Interface Designer
Method
Requirements:
Operate electronic devices
Universal
Possibly operate several different types of devices
Findings
Function of a remote control
	- send messages to the television set.
	Eg.:	"switch on“
			"switch to next channel“
			"switch to channel 9“
			"turn volume up"
Findings II
Complicated Remote
	- many functions
	- user will generally have
	  little use as it is complicated
	- BORING
Findings III
Simple Remote
Few functions
Easy for user to manipulate
Cheap look
BORING!
Personal Preferences
Revolutionize!!       
Attain the functionality of the complicated device
Attain simplicity through a new format of display (user interface)

Trend Watching
Presented by: Sara, Marketing Expert
Method
Look at remote control market demands
visual style
technical design
functionality
Look at current trends in design
fashion
interior design
advertising
Findings
Aesthetics
trends
fruits and vegetables
“spongy” feel
Design
innovative 
Interface
easy-to-use
Personal Preferences
Sleek clean lines
“Fancy” design features
Natural curves and colours to include current style trends
Reintroduce skin option, perhaps soft leather casing? Print cases?
Interface graphics

Design projects

24. Do you have experience with working in project teams?
No
Hardly any *
Average
A lot 

This document was truncated here because it was created in the Evaluation Mode.

Final Report
	The goal of our project was to create a Remote Control that would sell for 25 Euro and cost 12.5 Euro to make, per unit. Within these broad constraints and the specific constraints that we would include the company logo, no ‘Teletext’ technology, and that it would be TV-specific, there was a great deal of freedom.
	Ideas matured through healthy discussion and collection of data by the Marketing Expert, User Interface, and Industrial Designers. The process of decision making was reasonably democratic in the opinion of the Project Manager, but it is certainly possible that the Team Members had different opinions.
	There was considerable confusion about precisely what each individual was supposed to do between the ‘Function,’ ‘Concepts’ and ‘Detailed’ design phases, but this is largely due to the dynamic nature of the project.
	Ultimately, we were successful in designing a remote control, but we had to scrap the solar power idea for budgetary reasons.
Closing comments were largely positive. We all felt that it was a productive use of time.
-None of us used the whiteboard at all, possibly because we were hesitant to get up with the microphones on. On the other hand, the paper was used extensively, as most of us were really interested in the pens and their function. 
-the powerpoint templates were invaluable but some complained of only receiving blank slides. I received a full template, however, and the others commented that there was a large difference between how my presentations looked compared to theirs, almost certainly due to the template.
-we all had a good time roleplaying though I felt that I got too into it. The others were more able to keep reality and role separate. Perhaps because I play too many PC video games and have experience with role playing games? 
-we thought that in a real team more brainstorming would occur, perhaps if the stakes were higher?
-It was also generally held that initial stress and workload were higher than later on in the day.
-there was some confusion about what actions the ‘designers’ were supposed to take in between meetings
-all were satisfied with the level of democracy and leadership in the group and all felt that there was a large number of opportunities for creativity. However, no one necessarily broached this topic directly, it had to asked by myself, so reactions could be unreliable.
-the UID felt there was too much emphasis on his role

•  Example: on/off switch, on/off light 
•  How: take inspiration from other, similar designs; be creative 
User interface design 
•  Example: a push button in the form of a coffee bean, with a LED in it 
•  How: make a selection from existing interface solutions, or create a new one

This document was truncated here because it was created in the Evaluation Mode.

Concepts Meeting 
Opening remarks were made as well as auto-criticism by the P.M.
Presentations were made by all team members (see below for details)
Agreement was reached on what specific audience we’d target and what this RC would offer
Future assignments and prototype development were mentioned and begun
Industrial Designer: 
	-manufacturer has limited us to the number of materials available, it is possible that we could find another
	-there are issues of power source, chip count for touchscreen, and the option of visible light as an output as well as just infrared
	-it was recommended that we use a non-touchscreen, solar powered remote
Marketing Expert: 
	-‘Fancy,’ sleek design is in, and there is a recent interest in earth tones and a ‘natural’ look. 
	-it was recommended that the remote have a ‘squishy’ feel to the touch as this is popular amongst our target audience
User-Interface Designer: 
	-voice recognition is available in-house and so would require little to develop
	-advanced functionality is available as well and is similar to market standards, should we decide to incorporate it
	-it was recommended that the remote be ipod-sized with voice recognition and included recognizable colours and shapes
3. It was agreed that we’d develop a remote with voice recognition that had a non-remote-like shape.
	-the design should be simple with a slide or fold-out bay for advanced functions
4. The UID and ID were tasked to begin a prototype with these constraints in mind.

Detailed Design Minutes   -- Real Reaction 14/02/05
Present: Ron – User Interface Designer
	Nathan – Industrial Designer
	Sara – Marketing Expert
	Marty – Project Manger
Minutes from the last minute were summarized
The prototype for the RC was presented
Finances for the RC were discussed and recalculated to fit within general budget constraints – the solar cell was dropped in favour of just a battery to come in under budget.
Project Evaluation by Team Members was carried out

Initial Ideas
International: Universal
-possible functions,  build into other appliances?
-trade-off between size and functionality (crowding for multifunction)
-touch-screen remote, multiformat 
-material quality, ‘slickness’ 
-faceplates for the remote, possible similarities to PDAs, but no syluses
-paging button to help find remotes
-who are we marketing this for? Who’s going to use it? 
-trade-off between money and function.

Minutes from Functional Design Meeting
An Agenda was presented
Board Guidelines were presented and brief comments were made about their importance to this project
Findings from each team member were presented (see sub-sections below)
Questions for the future direction of the project were asked
Discussion was held 
Presentation by Nathan, Industrial Designer
	-pointed out safety and functional difficulties with metal casings for remote controls
	-suggested that we adopt plastic cases
	-explained function of remote controls 
Presentation by Ron, User Interface Designer
	-pointed out the cluttered design of most remote controls
	-emphasized simplicity and minimization of function
	-suggested strongly that we focus our design on novelty and maturity
Presentation by Sarah, Marketing Expert
	-most users only use the basic functions of remote controls
	-younger population is interested in voice recognition
	-current remote controls do not match function to behaviour
4. Future Directions
	It was conclude that we should focus this project on creating an RC that would be marketed to a younger audience primarily. We will look into incorporating touch screen technology and focus on simpler functions rather than attempt to please all customers.
	Image and cost will be of primary importance and finding a balance between these two polarities will be the ultimate aim for this project. Corporate restrictions will be met.
